      1973
      22 W 8th St
      New York, NY 10011
      United States
      (212) 533-2962

      The experience at this restaurant was absolutely fabulous. The food was great and would love to be able to go for dinner as I went for the more limited lunch menu. Our table had the duck, the mussels, and the French ravioli. Of those the duck was my favorite as it was incredibly moist, tender, and perfectly seasoned. Along with the food, the service is very good. Overall, they're attentive and very patient since our table stayed quite a while after our meal was done. Finally, they have a great selection of wines with their Pinot Noir Rose being an excellent choice.

      So disappointed. I was looking forward to coming here based off of all of their great reviews. Even now writing this review and seeing everyone else's on the right hand side- I'm not sure what happened. I came here for Sunday Brunch. Maybe thats the reason? Anywho.... FOOD/DRINKS I ordered the eggs benedict and absolutely hated it. Maybe I'm not a fan of the dish itself but the vegetables they used such as peppers and zucchini did not taste great. My cousin ordered the burger and she said it was simply okay and the place should get three stars. Their wine selection is pretty good, I ordered the riesling and it was delicious. Their cheese plate it amazing as well. SERVICE The staff is pretty friendly yet semi-aloof. It took a while for the waiter to come take our order but you can tell it was to allow us a moment to see what we wanted not rudeness. Once he came over he didn't introduce himself or anything but answered all questions and provided great recommendations. Once the food came he was nowhere to be found but he didn't bother during the meal. PRICE They are pretty pricey and personally for the brunch its not worth it. Im sure their regular menu is better [if there is a different one] but I wouldnt return. AMBIANCE The place is pretty small but spaced out in a manner that you dont feel too cluttered. Its very nice and simple outside and has a very cozy feel to it.

      When life gets me down, I often turn to charcuterie. I came in alone on a Saturday and the place was jam packed with no seats at the bar and an estimated 40 minute wait. I told the host I'd stick it out and wait for an opening. I guess he felt my need and ended up giving me a "not really a seat" without a back at the very tip of the end of the bar. I was so grateful. I sat on my corner, barely spoke to anyone, and treated myself to a really luxurious meal. First I had half a dozen oysters; they're served with a mignonette instead of a cocktail sauce. I prefer cocktail, but this wasn't so heavy on the vinegar and I ended up being quite happy with it. The oysters were fresh and delicious. Also, let it be noted that any place that allows me to order both a cheese board and oysters has to work hard to make me dislike them. I did a 5 piece charcuterie plate to start: smoked duck breast, sopressatta, camembert, tete de moine, and brilliant savarin. The brilliant ended up being my favorite cheese, all were on the mild side which was fine by me. The duck was so delicious, and the sopressatta was excellent quality. They also give you so many fixins: two chutneys, a mustard sauce, pickles, caramelized onions, grapes, dried apricots, dried cranberries, and nuts. This might be the most decked out board I've ever ordered, and I blissfully savored each bite, mixing and matching things together till it felt like my tongue was doing cartwheels. I also ordered the charred Spanish octopus that comes in a ratatouille with harissa aioli. I know that sounds busy, and it is a bit when compared with the other things I ordered, but the octopus was really, really good. It might have been the most tender I've been served, and the char was perfect. If you want to focus more on that texture and flavor, get it without the aioli but even if you keep it on, it won't distract as much as it sounds like it will. Finally I finished up with a warm apple tart and vanilla ice cream. My only complaint is that there could have been a little more ice cream, but this was delicious and not overpoweringly sweet. Service was impeccable. Friendly, attentive. And I can't stay enough nice things about the menu. This is a new favorite!

      It's truly my happy place in NYC. I lost counts of how many time I have been here. They have great options of wine, and the waiters always give you great recommendations. And I love love love their gigantic wine glass. They have great appetizers. Couple recommendations: Goat cheese ball - a must try, eat it with their bread, it's delicious. Crostini - the mango one is my favorite. $3 each or $21 try all the flavors. Salmon tartare - used to be one of my fav, but I went back last Friday, I couldn't find it on the new menu, so I ordered tuna tartare, the presentation of the dish is alright, and the taste is not as good. steamed mussels, and the new PES mussels - it's fresh and delicious, dip the bread into the soup, it tastes amazing. Tsucan kale salad - delicious, a perfect balance between fruits and veggies. Fondant au chocolat - my favorite dessert of theirs Banana cream brulee - One of the best cream brulee ive had Not just about the food, the services here is the reason why I keep coming back. The waiters, bartenders, managers are all very friendly and make you feel welcomed. I definitely recommend this place for groups and dates. Dont forget to make a reservation cause this place is always packed.

      Amelie is quite lovely! I found my eyes wandering a lot to check out all the design quirks around the room. The room itself is dimly lit with a soft, red glow. We started out with happy hour specials (which is every day until 7 pm). Along with an offering of a variety of wine flights for $12, the goat cheese and escargot were also offered at happy hour prices. The goat cheese was probably my favorite dish of the night. The goat cheese was crusted with finely powdered pistachio, on top of a bed of pickled onions and honey. This had nutty, tangy, acidity and sweetness, and was a great balance of flavors. Make sure to smear it all over the delicious baguette! I also tried escargot for the first time, despite studying abroad in Paris and subsequent travels to thereafter. I am still not quite ready for it, I think, as I wanted the parsley sauce to be much more assertive to mask the taste of the escargot meat a bit. But my mom quite enjoyed it, so there you go. We also shared the ratatouille to balance out all the creaminess and butter. It was a well prepared ratatouille, but I wouldn't go out of my way to order it again. For my entree, I ordered the duck confit, which was FABULOUS. The kitchen achieved that tantalizing crispy skin with the fall-off-the-bone tender meat inside. It was so juicy, and the jus coated the fingerling potatoes and mushrooms with a delicate balance of umami flavor. I also appreciated the frisee salad on top, which brightened up the dish considerably. I was actually surprised by how fresh this salad was - it wasn't wilted in any way and looked like the kitchen just got the salad from the market that day. We finished off the meal with the creme de citron. Oh gawd, if you are a lover of lemon/lime things, you must get this! The creme de citron packs a punch of acidity without being overwhelming. It is balanced out beautifully by the fresh oranges and grapefruits. The dish was served with almond crackers (not a crumble in contrast to what the menu says). But yummy regardless.

      It was raining on a Saturday Night of February 17th 2018. I made reservations here with my girlfriend for 7pm. The receptionist area is at the back of the restaurant so we walked over and stated my name. The guy stated I already checked in as he said "wait a minute here I think someone try to make a fool of me". I thought it was hilarious haha as he seated us right away after the confusion and given us the menu and the wine selections. Service: The waiter gave us water and bread right at the start. The bread was warm and tasted so good. This was the first time I could eat bread without butter. The bread was already delicious without it haha. We began looking through the menu. The wine menu was probably larger than the actual dinner menu. Food: We were excited to try the Roasted Duck Leg Confit with wine. We started off with the appetizer which was the Hand Cut Steak Tartare, then 2 orders of the Roasted Duck Leg Confit. The steak Tartare looked very small on the plate, but just a small piece of the tartare just melted in my mouth and the tartare matched well with the bread as I put both together and it was just simply delicious. We waited for our main course as the bread was already done after the appetizer. To get more bread, you will need to let the waiter know because the restaurant is so busy that they don't really check for you from my experience here so far. The Roasted Duck Leg Confit looked so good as there was some vegetables on the bottom of the duck leg. The duck was very juicy and I took my time to enjoy each and every bite as my girlfriend devoured it 5 minutes after I finished. Advice: make sure you get wine that pairs well with your meal otherwise you will not get the whole experience. Overall: Its definitely a nice place for special occasions.

      This review is for the wine flights and small plates. I like this place because they have $12 wine flights which come with 3 glasses. They are very generous with the wine portions. I basically felt like I had 3 actual glasses of wine.       Popular bistro vibe wine bar/restaurant in West Village. Best known for their well-priced wine flights at happy hour - $12 for your choice of three wines from 4-7pm every day (including weekends). They have a nice, but limited menu with the usual French appetizer and dishes. Tried many of their small plates including the crostini (every flavor on the menu), foie gras, cheeses, charcuterie, etc which were all tasty with wine. The only downside is that this restaurant is always busy and packed. Tables are too small and too close to each other to the point where you are practically dining with the people next to you. Not the place for quiet conversation or the best meal choice for a quiet meal. However, great place for wine/happy hour.

      Great ambiance with some really nice deals--happy hour consists of lovely wine flights for $12. Chicken liver mousse is DELICIOUS and comes with pickled cauliflower and carrots, caramelized onions, mustard and baguette. For the entrees, I got the duck confit (yum) and the boyfriend got the coq au vin (even more yum). All very tasty. A star is taken off only for the price since I've had equally delicious food in a nearby area for less. Still, would come back!

      Saturday brunch before yoga Pros: Perfect amount of food. Very friendly waiter. The place is decorated like inside of a yacht. No waiting time! Cons: Table is a bit too small.

      Great food and cozy, social atmosphere. The food was delicious. We came in on an evening to celebrate a friend's birthday with a rather large party (10+ people) and we had reservations seated at a table in the back. Luckily we were able to sit down, enjoy some drinks and appetizers while we waited for the rest of our group to join us. The server was charming and charismatic, chatting and joking with our party between ordering and refilling our water. Our party started off with appetizers of the escargot which disappeared as quickly as they came. Many excellent choices for French cuisine and cooking techniques were represented in the menu - Duck confit, foie gras, ravioles du royans (tiny ravioles filled with herbs & cheese) baked au gratin, and even humble dishes like the ratatouille. Our server accompanied us well and we left the restaurant well satisfied. A lovely spot to celebrate a special occasion amongst close family and friends.

      Reserved a spot Friday night for my bf's birthday dinner and despite running late the staff was super accommodating! Called twice pushing back our reservation because of the traffic and despite being almost an hour late, they had table for us. When we got there, we were immediately seated but the place was sooo cramped, the intimate dinner I was hoping for wasn't too intimate as I could basically hear the conversations from the couples next to us. We also had our glasses almost knocked over whenever someone would go up to leave. Perhaps if we got there on time, we could have snagged a table in the corner? Either way we immediately ordered a bottle of red wine to share and the flatbread Margherita pizza to start off with. Both were delicious! They have a ton of appetizers that are veggie friendly but just one entree that's vegetarian. So I got the classic ravioli entree, to my surprise was actually pretty filling! My bf got the duck entree and he was pleased! The service was good, the servers checked up on us if we needed anything and while we were hoping to get desert there just wasn't any room for it. Before we left, I headed to the bathroom and to my dismay saw a male worker walk out the female bathroom. I get it if you have to go you gotta go but be quick and clean about it. Overall, the food and wine was good but I'd have to knock out a star for the limited vegetarian options and cramped space.

        When life gets me down, I often turn to charcuterie. I came in alone on a Saturday and the place was jam packed with no seats at the bar and an estimated 40 minute wait. I told the host I'd stick it out and wait for an opening. I guess he felt my need and ended up giving me a "not really a seat" without a back at the very tip of the end of the bar. I was so grateful.

        I sat on my corner, barely spoke to anyone, and treated myself to a really luxurious meal.

        First I had half a dozen oysters; they're served with a mignonette instead of a cocktail sauce. I prefer cocktail, but this wasn't so heavy on the vinegar and I ended up being quite happy with it. The oysters were fresh and delicious. Also, let it be noted that any place that allows me to order both a cheese board and oysters has to work hard to make me dislike them.

        I did a 5 piece charcuterie plate to start: smoked duck breast, sopressatta, camembert, tete de moine, and brilliant savarin. The brilliant ended up being my favorite cheese, all were on the mild side which was fine by me. The duck was so delicious, and the sopressatta was excellent quality. They also give you so many fixins: two chutneys, a mustard sauce, pickles, caramelized onions, grapes, dried apricots, dried cranberries, and nuts. This might be the most decked out board I've ever ordered, and I blissfully savored each bite, mixing and matching things together till it felt like my tongue was doing cartwheels.

        I also ordered the charred Spanish octopus that comes in a ratatouille with harissa aioli. I know that sounds busy, and it is a bit when compared with the other things I ordered, but the octopus was really, really good. It might have been the most tender I've been served, and the char was perfect. If you want to focus more on that texture and flavor, get it without the aioli but even if you keep it on, it won't distract as much as it sounds like it will.

        Finally I finished up with a warm apple tart and vanilla ice cream. My only complaint is that there could have been a little more ice cream, but this was delicious and not overpoweringly sweet.

        Service was impeccable. Friendly, attentive. And I can't stay enough nice things about the menu. This is a new favorite!

        3/10/2018
        • Seated via Yelp Reservations

        Amelie is quite lovely! I found my eyes wandering a lot to check out all the design quirks around the room. The room itself is dimly lit with a soft, red glow.

        We started out with happy hour specials (which is every day until 7 pm). Along with an offering of a variety of wine flights for $12, the goat cheese and escargot were also offered at happy hour prices.

        The goat cheese was probably my favorite dish of the night. The goat cheese was crusted with finely powdered pistachio, on top of a bed of pickled onions and honey. This had nutty, tangy, acidity and sweetness, and was a great balance of flavors. Make sure to smear it all over the delicious baguette!

        I also tried escargot for the first time, despite studying abroad in Paris and subsequent travels to thereafter. I am still not quite ready for it, I think, as I wanted the parsley sauce to be much more assertive to mask the taste of the escargot meat a bit. But my mom quite enjoyed it, so there you go.

        We also shared the ratatouille to balance out all the creaminess and butter. It was a well prepared ratatouille, but I wouldn't go out of my way to order it again.

        For my entree, I ordered the duck confit, which was FABULOUS. The kitchen achieved that tantalizing crispy skin with the fall-off-the-bone tender meat inside. It was so juicy, and the jus coated the fingerling potatoes and mushrooms with a delicate balance of umami flavor. I also appreciated the frisee salad on top, which brightened up the dish considerably. I was actually surprised by how fresh this salad was - it wasn't wilted in any way and looked like the kitchen just got the salad from the market that day.

        We finished off the meal with the creme de citron. Oh gawd, if you are a lover of lemon/lime things, you must get this! The creme de citron packs a punch of acidity without being overwhelming. It is balanced out beautifully by the fresh oranges and grapefruits. The dish was served with almond crackers (not a crumble in contrast to what the menu says). But yummy regardless.

        It was raining on a Saturday Night of February 17th 2018.  I made reservations here with my girlfriend for 7pm.  The receptionist area is at the back of the restaurant so we walked over and stated my name.  The guy stated I already checked in as he said "wait a minute here I think someone try to make a fool of me".  I thought it was hilarious haha as he seated us right away after the confusion and given us the menu and the wine selections.

        Service: The waiter gave us water and bread right at the start.  The bread was warm and tasted so good.  This was the first time I could eat bread without butter.  The bread was already delicious without it haha.  We began looking through the menu.  The wine menu was probably larger than the actual dinner menu.

        Food: We were excited to try the Roasted Duck Leg Confit with wine.  We started off with the appetizer which was the Hand Cut Steak Tartare, then 2 orders of the Roasted Duck Leg Confit.  The steak Tartare looked very small on the plate, but just a small piece of the tartare just melted in my mouth and the tartare matched well with the bread as I put both together and it was just simply delicious.  We waited for our main course as the bread was already done after the appetizer.  To get more bread, you will need to let the waiter know because the restaurant is so busy that they don't really check for you from my experience here so far.  The Roasted Duck Leg Confit looked so good as there was some vegetables on the bottom of the duck leg.  The duck was very juicy and I took my time to enjoy each and every bite as my girlfriend devoured it 5 minutes after I finished.

        Advice:  make sure you get wine that pairs well with your meal otherwise you will not get the whole experience.

        Overall: Its definitely a nice place for special occasions.

        Popular bistro vibe wine bar/restaurant in West Village. Best known for their well-priced wine flights at happy hour -  $12 for your choice of three wines from 4-7pm every day (including weekends). They have a nice, but limited menu with the usual French appetizer and dishes. Tried many of their small plates including the crostini (every flavor on the menu), foie gras, cheeses, charcuterie, etc which were all tasty with wine.

        The only downside is that this restaurant is always busy and packed. Tables are too small and too close to each other to the point where you are practically dining with the people next to you.  Not the place for quiet conversation or the best meal choice for a quiet meal. However, great place for wine/happy hour.

      From the business

      Since it opened its doors in San Francisco five years ago, Amélie wine bar has become one of the most successful wine bars in the city, attracting an eclectic crowd of people every …

      Learn more about Amélie , Opens a popup

      Specialties

      Since it opened its doors in San Francisco five years ago, Amélie wine bar has become one of the most successful wine bars in the city, attracting an eclectic crowd of people every night of the week.

      "Our intention was to make good wine accessible, affordable and fun," said Germain, a co-owner and manager.

      With its euro-chic décor, sensual lighting and "the best bar music in the city" (7x7), Amélie bar has changed the way good wine is enjoyed and consumed. Patrons appreciate the generous pour, the low turnover of the staff, the international flair, and the great choice of good wines at fair prices.
